name: Sirens
title: Greek - The Sirens
role: Deadly Singers, Luring Sailors to Destruction
summary: The Sirens are the deadly singers of Homer's Odyssey whose irresistible song lures sailors to their deaths on rocky shores. Warned by Circe, Odysseus had his men plug their ears with wax while he alone, tied to the mast, heard their song - the only mortal to hear and survive. Their song promised knowledge of all things, and Homer describes a meadow of bones surrounding their island.
description: The Sirens are divine singers in Homer's Odyssey who lure sailors to shipwreck with their irresistible song. Circe warns Odysseus of them, advising he plug his crew's ears with wax. Odysseus alone, bound to the mast, hears their song of all knowledge and survives. They embody fatal temptation and forbidden knowledge.

homeric_context.role_in_epic: One of the perils Odysseus must navigate on his journey home

the_episode.circes_warning: Circe warns Odysseus of the Sirens and advises how to pass safely
the_episode.the_precaution: Odysseus has his men plug their ears with softened beeswax
the_episode.odysseus_bound: Odysseus is tied to the mast so he can hear but not respond
the_episode.the_song: The Sirens promise knowledge of all that happens on earth
the_episode.the_temptation: Odysseus begs to be released but his men, as ordered, bind him tighter
the_episode.the_escape: They row past safely; Odysseus is the only mortal to hear and survive

homeric_context.what_they_promise: Come hither, famous Odysseus... we know all that happens on the earth

the_solution.for_crew: Beeswax in the ears - they cannot hear the song
the_solution.for_odysseus: Bound to the mast - he hears but cannot act
the_solution.significance: Demonstrates the value of forethought and self-control

victims: Countless sailors whose bones litter their meadow
survivor: Odysseus - the only mortal to hear their song and live
